repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Private Sector Development
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Support Project for Afghanistan were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            recent reviews and studies on international experience
            relating to industrial parks (and special economic zones)
            also suggest that a more efficient approach to the
            development of IPs is to rely on public private
            partnerships, where the private sector is responsible for
            the construction and management of parks. 'Flexibility
            in design' can seem an evasive concept in an
            infrastructure project. However, the deterioration of
            security (or the lack of long term visibility and possible
            change of environment) should probably always, at least, be
            considered a risk in a conflict context. In this respect,
            options to quickly reorient the use of Project funds might
            have been identified at preparation, for example, to support
            other IPs already under construction with the support of
            other donors. The decision to use Afghanistan Investment
            Support Authority (AISA), supported by individual
            consultants, to undertake the construction of the industrial
            park appears, in retrospect, to have been ill-informed.
            Building an industrial park requires a variety of highly
            specialized expertise that only an engineering firm can
            mobilize. While the focus on building AISA's capacity
            was well founded, the approach to build its capacity through
            individual consultants was not appropriate, when it came to
            building a large industrial park.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Private Sector Development
            Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The private sector development support
            project for Afghanistan aims to increase the volume of
            private investment and productive jobs in Afghanistan. The
            specific goals that will contribute to this are: to enhance
            the provision of land and infrastructural services for
            enterprise development; to enhance the capacity of
            government agencies to analyze private sector development
            (PSD) issues, and develop and implement PSD-related
            strategies, policies and programs. Enhance the capacity of
            government agencies to promote Afghanistan as an investment
            destination and provide investment facilitation services. By
            helping to address the land constraint, this project will
            attract private investment in a variety of sectors,
            including but not limited to manufacturing, agribusiness,
            and smaller scale infrastructure projects. The industrial
            park will help stimulate the local economy generate
            employment, and raise much needed tax revenues.

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Private Sector Development
            Support Project : environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Private Sector
            Development Support Project for Afghanistan is to improve
            the investment climate in Afghanistan for foreign and
            domestic firms by : enhance the provision of land and
            infrastructural services for enterprise development; enhance
            the capacity of government agencies to analyze PSD issues,
            and develop and implement PSD-related strategies, policies
            and programs; and enhance the capacity of government
            agencies to promote Afghanistan as an investment destination
            and provide investment facilitation services. This
            Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) document evaluated
            impacts and suggests mitigation measures in the following
            areas : road network; storm water drainage; air quality;
            noise levels; topography; soil contamination; seismology;
            solid waste management system; hydrogeology; loss of
            endangered species both flora and fauna; wastewater
            collection and disposal system; water resources; surface and
            ground water quality; religious, archeological monuments and
            historical sites findings; health, safety and environmental
            procedures; institutional arrangement for implementation of
            the EIA; on-job training and training centers; employment
            opportunities; finally, applicability of Afghanistan's
            National policy and administrative framework, law on private
            investment in Afghanistan, environmental policy Act, land
            acquisition Act, and the Bank's operational safeguard
            directives on environmental and social matters
